A study of literature dealing with the fantastic or containing supernatural or uncanny elements.  This course may include
samples of myth, romance, Gothic literature, and fantasy from a variety of periods.
ENGL 273.title: Literature and the Fantastic
PREREQUISITE: A grade of C in ENGL 100/6.0.

SOCY 476.description:
Advanced study of surveillance engaging with sociological, political, cultural and geographic perspectives. The focus is on
core topics in Surveillance Studies including: the relationship between surveillance, power and social control; the concept of
privacy, its history, utility and future; surveillance, pleasure and consumption; and surveillance in popular culture.
SOCY 476.title: Advanced Topics in Surveillance Studies
PREREQUISITE:
Level 4 and registration in a SOCY Major or Medial Plan and SOCY 309/3.0 and  (a minimum grade of C in
SOCY 210/3.0 and SOCY 211/3.0 and SOCY 226/3.0 and SOCY 227/3.0) and (a minimum GPA of 2.60 in SOCY 210/3.0 and
SOCY 211/3.0 and SOCY 226/3.0 and SOCY 227/3.0) and (a minimum GPA of 2.60 in all SOCY).

EXCLUSION: No more than 6.0 units from DRAM 200/6.0; DRAM 201/3.0; DRAM 202/3.0; DRAM 210/6.0.
DRAM 200.description:
A chronological survey of production methods, architecture, performance, and dramatic literature in western and eastern
theatre traditions from early classical eras to the end of the 19th century.
DRAM 200.title: Theatre History and Literature I
PREREQUISITE: Level 2 or above.

EXCLUSION: No more than 3.0 units from LLCU 332/3.0; SPAN 332/3.0.
LLCU 332.description:
Short theatre played an important role in the theatre of Spanish Golden Age. In this course students will study the literary
particularities of the genre and the social ramifications of the themes present in short theatre (gender, battle of the sexes,
diversity, authority amongst others) and their historical and contemporary relevance.
NOTE: Readings are in translation.
LLCU 332.title: Spanish Baroque Short Theatre
PREREQUISITE: Level 3 or permission of the Department of Languages, Literatures and Cultures.

DEVS 501.description:
The course will involve a critical review of the literature on a clearly-defined topic relevant to development, a synthesis of
ideas, and a final thesis under the supervision of a faculty member.
NOTE:
The student must identify a willing supervisor from DEVS or a cognate department and receive permission of the
Department of Global Development Studies.
DEVS 501.title: Honours Thesis in Development Studies
PREREQUISITE: Minimum Cumulative GPA of 3.50 and Level 4 and registration in the DEVS Major or Medial Plan.

EMPR 250.description:
This course introduces students to employment relations practices and legislative frameworks related to workplace health
and wellness. The course examines roles and responsibilities of employers, employees, and unions in occupational health
and safety. Students will explore efforts to address stress and promote wellness, including mental health.
EMPR 250.title: Managing Workplace Health, Safety, and Wellness
PREREQUISITE: Level 2 or above.

PHYS 313.description:
Introduction to Linux and a programming language. Foundations and limitations of numerical calculations. Code
development, debugging, optimization and profiling. Algorithms and techniques used in physics problems. Possible topics to
be covered include numerical differentiation and integration, root finding and optimization problems, solution of linear
systems of equations, Monte Carlo simulations, symbolic computation.
PHYS 313.title: Computational Methods in Physics
PREREQUISITE:
(PHYS 212/3.0 and PHYS 239/3.0) and (MATH 221/3.0 or MATH 280/3.0) and (MATH 225/3.0 or MATH
231/3.0 or MATH 232/3.0).

GEOL 282.description:
Managing Earth Systems: Resources and Environment
An earth-system engineering perspective on the nature, acquisition and utilization of energy, mineral and water resources,
with particular emphasis on the environmental considerations in their extraction, processing, and use. Criteria for designing
resource exploration programs are examined. Practical exercises, projects and seminars (team and individual) deal with
these issues, and include the design of risk-management plans, environmental life-cycle assessments, sustainable systems
and ore-reserve estimations.
PREREQUISITE: GEOL 221/3.0 or GEOL 232/3.0, or permission of the Department.

CISC 490.description: Content varies. Not offered every year.
CISC 490.title: Topics in Computing Science I
PREREQUISITE: Permission of the instructor.

PSYC 495.description: Seminar and lab course on an advanced topic in psychology offered periodically by visiting professors.
NOTE:
Prerequisites vary depending on specific course content; consult instructor or Undergraduate Office in the
Psychology Department.
PSYC 495.title: Advanced Topic in Psychology

RELS 331.description:
Links between violence and religious beliefs, practices and institutions; for example, sacrifice, holy wars, scapegoating, and
suicide.
RELS 331.title: Religion and Violence
PREREQUISITE: Level 3 or above or 6.0 units at the 100 level in RELS.

POLS 511.description:
Students arrange their course of reading in consultation with members of the Department. They are expected to write
reports on their readings and to discuss them in seminars.
POLS 511.title: Directed Special Reading
PREREQUISITE:
Level 4 and (registration in a POLS Major or Medial Plan) and POLS 250/6.0 and (a GPA of 2.5 on all units in
POLS).

PSYC 351.description:
An overview of the development of emotions and their regulation. Topics range from basic emotions in infancy and
interactions with caregivers that lay the foundations of socialized behaviour to the emotional upheaval and radical social
changes of adolescence. Individual differences in social and emotional behaviour will be considered in light of both typical
and atypical development.
PSYC 351.title: Social and Emotional Development

PHGY 350.description:
An introductory course in Pathophysiology in which the underlying functional changes of cell and cell systems will be
discussed in association with a variety of disease processes.
PHGY 350.title: Pathophysiology
PREREQUISITE: PHGY 210/6.0 or PHGY 214/6.0 or (KNPE 125/3.0 and KNPE 225/3.0) or PHGY 212/6.0.

GEOL 200.title: Oceanography
PREREQUISITE:
PHYS 104/6.0 or PHYS 106/6.0 or PHYS 107/6.0 or PHYS 117/6.0 or CHEM 112/6.0 or BIOL 102/3.0 or BIOL
103/3.0 or GEOL 104/3.0 or GEOL 106/3.0 or GEOL 107/3.0.

LLCU 501.description:
This course enables a student or a group of students to explore a body of literature on a selected topic in Languages,
Literatures, and Cultures. The focus may be by theme, by region, or academic approach and can span the humanities, social
sciences, and environmental sciences.
NOTE:
The student(s) is responsible for approaching a professor with whom they wish to work and who is willing to
undertake this project.
LLCU 501.title: Directed Readings in Languages, Literatures and Cultures
PREREQUISITE: Level 3 or permission of the Department of Languages, Literatures and Cultures.

ARTH 342.description:
Through lectures, readings, and research, this course explores the nature, practice, and impact of photography in Canada
between 1839 and 1939. By examining how the new medium was used to confirm, complement, and contest older forms of
aesthetic expression, written documentation, or visual evidence, it traces the role of photography in Canadian society
during this critical period of Canadian nation building.
ARTH 342.title: Photography in Canada 1839-1939
PREREQUISITE: Level 3 or above.

EXCLUSION: No more than 1 course from HIST 278/3.0; HIST 313/6.0.
HIST 313.description:
This course will survey the political, social, economic, and cultural development of the British colonies that became Canada
from the conquest of Quebec to Confederation. Native-newcomer relations, the maturation of settler societies, and new
institutional structures will receive special attention. Different historical approaches and the use of primary sources will be
emphasized.
HIST 313.title: ritish North America, 1759-1867
PREREQUISITE: Registration in a HIST Major or Medial Plan.

GPHY 207.description:
An examination of ecological and earth system processes that affect the dynamics of organisms, their spatial patterns and
their variability in time.
GPHY 207.title: Principles of Biogeography
PREREQUISITE: 3.0 units from GPHY 102/3.0; BIOL; GEOL or permission of the Department.

GRMN 201.description:
A continuation of GRMN 102/3.0 aimed at expanding basic language skills (listening, reading, writing and speaking). Students will
review and deepen their knowledge of grammatical structures through exposure to a variety of German-language media and
culture.
GRMN 201.title: Intermediate German I
PREREQUISITE: A grade of C in GRMN 102/3.0 or permission of the Department of Languages, Literatures and Cultures.

ECON 411.description: Content varies from year to year. Game theory, risk, and externalities are among the topics covered in recent years.
ECON 411.title: Topics in Microeconomic Theory

FREN 285.description: A course focusing on the socio-cultural and political aspects of African and Caribbean cinemas.
FREN 285.title: Cinéma et société: aspects culturels de la francophonie
PREREQUISITE: FREN 150/6.0 or (FREN 101/3.0 and FREN 102/3.0) or FREN 100/6.0 or FREN 110/6.0.

GNDS 340.description:
Examines scholarship, creative works, and activism by Indigenous women as a basis for introducing Indigenous feminist
thought. Cases examine the many ways that Indigenous women and LGBTQ/Two-Spirit people participate in Indigenous
nations, experience and resist settler colonialism, and work for Indigenous decolonization.
GNDS 340.title: Indigenous Women, Feminism and Resistance
PREREQUISITE: Level 3 or permission of the Department.

GPHY 209.description:
The principles of energy and water exchange between the atmosphere, surface and subsurface. The hydrological cycle,
radiation, and energy balances are used as conceptual frameworks.
GPHY 209.title: Principles of Hydroclimatology
PREREQUISITE: GPHY 102/3.0 or permission of the Department.

POLS 461.description:
An exploration of problems of order and change in the international system with particular attention to the theory and
practice of co-operation, ranging from classic concepts of international organization to current debates about international
regimes.
POLS 461.title: International Regimes
PREREQUISITE:
Level 4 and (registration in a POLS Major or Medial Plan) and POLS 250/6.0 and (a GPA of 2.5 on all units in
POLS).

ARTH 421.description: A detailed study of one area or topic in the history of early 20th-century art.
ARTH 421.title: Topics in Early 20th-century Visual and Material Culture
PREREQUISITE:
A GPA of 2.60 in a minimum of 24.0 units in ARTH courses and Level 4 and registration in an ARTH Major or
Medial Plan.

INTS 324.description:
A study of thematic and stylistic approaches to the representation of selected cultures and to the presentation and
evocation of global issues in one or more of the fine, performing or media arts. Topics will vary each year. For detailed
course description, see www.queensu.ca/bisc
NOTE: Offered only at the Bader International Study Centre, Herstmonceux.
INTS 324.title: International Perspectives in the Creative Arts II
PREREQUISITE: Level 2 in the relevant arts discipline.

ENGL 482.description: For detailed information, consult the Department.
ENGL 482.title: Topics in Indigenous Literatures II
PREREQUISITE:
(ENGL 200/6.0 and ENGL 290/3.0) and (a GPA of 2.4 on all ENGL units) and (registration in an ENGL Major
or Medial Plan).

ECON 423.title: Topics in Financial Economics
PREREQUISITE:
ECON 310/3.0 and ECON 322/3.0.
COREQUISITE    ECON 351/3.0.

ENSC 301.description:
The course explores components of environmental assessment including public consultation, scoping, alternatives,
protocols, significance, trade-offs, mitigation and monitoring. Biophysical, cumulative, social, strategic and sustainability
assessment through case studies highlight strengths and weaknesses of the environmental assessment process.
ENSC 301.title: Environmental Assessment
PREREQUISITE: Level 3 or above.

PSYC 342.description:
This course reviews theory and research on the processes by which people exert influence on one another’s behaviours,
beliefs, emotions, and attitudes. Topics of study include conformity, compliance, obedience, and persuasion. The course
will focus on both the theoretical and applied implications of social influence research.
NOTE: Also offered at the Bader International Study Centre, Herstmonceux. Learning Hours may vary.
PSYC 342.title: The Psychology of Social Influence

EXCLUSION: No more than 3.0 units from APSC 142/3.0; CISC 101/3.0; CISC 110/3.0.
CISC 110.description:
Introduction to fundamental programming concepts in the context of visual, interactive media. Students may develop
applications in any domain (e.g., fine art, education, commerce, physical or social sciences) while learning about algorithms,
program design, logic, program control flow, functions, testing, etc.
NOTE: No computing or art background required.
ONE-WAY EXCLUSION: May not be taken with or after CISC 121/3.0.
CISC 110.title: Creative Computing

EXCLUSION: No more than 3.0 units from CLST 330/3.0; CLST 333/3.0.
CLST 333.description:
Study of the rise of Athenian power from the end of the Persian Wars in 479 BCE, and the conflict between Athens and
Sparta along with their allies during the Peloponnesian War (431-404 BCE). Topics may include the Delian League and
Athenian imperialism, development of radical democracy in Athens, and causes and effects of the Peloponnesian War.
CLST 333.title: The Rise of the Athenian Empire to the End of the Peloponnesian War
PREREQUISITE: CLST 200/3.0 or permission of the Department.

EXCLUSION: No more than 1 course from ARTF 101/3.0; ARTF 105/6.0; ARTF 106/3.0; ARTF 127/6.0.
ARTF 106.description:
An exploration, through the processes of drawing and painting, of a wide variety of visual problems encountered by the
contemporary artist.
NOTE:
Not available for credit towards a B.F.A. program.
Materials: estimated cost $200.
ARTF 106.title: Introductory Fine Art (Drawing and Painting)

EXCLUSION:
No more than 3.0 units from LLCU 316/3.0; SPAN 316/3.0; SPAN 406/3.0.
EQUIVALENCY    SPAN 316/3.0.
LLCU 316.description:
An introduction to contemporary literary theories and the analysis of Hispanic texts from reader-, structural-, and author-
oriented perspectives.
LLCU 316.title: Introduction to Contemporary Literary Theory and Analysis
PREREQUISITE: Level 3 or permission of the Department of Languages, Literatures and Cultures.

ENGL 464.description:
A study of the theory and practice of modernist writers in Britain and North America. Texts will include theoretical
manifestoes as well as creative writing. Some attention will be given to the modernist movement in other arts.
ENGL 464.title: Literary Modernism
PREREQUISITE:
(ENGL 200/6.0 and ENGL 290/3.0) and (a GPA of 2.4 on all ENGL units) and (registration in an ENGL Major
or Medial Plan).

HEBR 393.description:
Selections from current Israeli media including music, newspapers and television, as well as from modern Hebrew prose and
poetry (e.g., Ahad Haam, Bialik, Tchernichowski, Agnon, Amichai, Oz, Yehoshua). The selections are studied in Hebrew; written
assignments may be submitted in English.
HEBR 393.title: Reading Modern Hebrew Literature

HIST 391.description:
Seminar on a selected topic in Canadian history. Topics change from year to year; course is either being offered for the first
time or is being taught by visiting faculty. Consult department office or website for details.
HIST 391.title: opics in Canadian History
PREREQUISITE: A Grade of C+ in 6.0 units from HIST 300-329 and registration in a HIST Major or Medial Plan.

SPAN 496.description: Seminar courses on topics in Spanish American literature. Course details to be announced on website.
SPAN 496.title: Literatura de Hispanoamérica: Estudios independientes II
PREREQUISITE:
Level 4 and registration in a SPAN Major or SLAS Specialization Plan or permission of the Department of
Languages Literatures and Cultures.

ENGL 450.description: For detailed information, consult the Department.
ENGL 450.title: Studies in Victorian Literature
PREREQUISITE:
(ENGL 200/6.0 and ENGL 290/3.0) and (a GPA of 2.4 on all ENGL units) and (registration in an ENGL Major
or Medial Plan).

POLS 485.description: An examination of key issues in gender and politics. Topics will vary from year to year; consult the departmental homepage.
POLS 485.title: Seminar in Gender and Politics
PREREQUISITE:
Level 4 and (registration in a POLS Major or Medial Plan) and POLS 250/6.0 and (a GPA of 2.5 on all units in
POLS).

EXCLUSION: No more than 3.0 units from CHEM 212/3.0; CHEM 281/3.0.
CHEM 212.description:
An introduction to the kinetics and mechanisms of reactions in gaseous and condensed phases, including acid-base and
nucleophilic substitution reactions at carbon and other main group centers. Other topics will include molecular dynamics
and reactions in solution. The laboratory illustrates measurement techniques and develops laboratory skills.
CHEM 212.title: Principles of Chemical Reactivity
PREREQUISITE:
CHEM 112/6.0 and (MATH 120/6.0 or MATH 121/6.0 or MATH 122/6.0 or [MATH 123/3.0 and MATH
124/3.0]).

EXCLUSION: No more than 1 course from HIST 515/6.0; HIST 517/3.0.
HIST 517.description:
The paper may be either a research project involving the use of primary and secondary sources, or a more broadly
conceived independent reading program.
NOTE:
Students must obtain the approval of the supervising instructor and of the Undergraduate Committee for any
project submitted.
HIST 517.title: ndependent Study Project
PREREQUISITE: Level 4 and (registered in a HIST Major or Medial Plan) and (a GPA of 3.30) and (30.0 units in HIST).

EXCLUSION: No more than 3.0 units from GPHY 401/3.0; GPHY 402/3.0; GPHY 403/3.0.
GPHY 402.description:
Seminars offered by regular and visiting faculty on Geography topics related to their research interests. Consult the
departmental homepage for further details of specific course offerings each academic year.
NOTE:
Field trip fees may apply in certain years. See departmental webpage for more information. Cost will vary
depending on location, but not likely to exceed $300 per year.
GPHY 402.title: Honours Seminar in Human Geography II
PREREQUISITE: Level 4 and (a GPA of 2.60 in 24.0 units in GPHY and registration in a GPHY Major or Medial [Arts] Plan).

HIST 446.description:
This course explores sex, gender, man, woman, as products of particular cultural and scientific contexts, drawing on South
Asian material. Themes include sexuality in Hindu mythology, colonial masculinity, sex and the body in Gandhi’s thought,
the gendered underpinnings of imperial ideologies, transnational feminism and its postcolonial critics, and the expression of
queer identities in South Asia.
HIST 446.title: ender, Sexuality and Race in South Asia
PREREQUISITE: A Grade of C+ in 6.0 units from HIST 300-329 and registration in a HIST Major or Medial Plan.

POLS 261.description:
International Politics
An introduction to the major issues in the study of international relations: questions of war and peace, national security,
the role of the ‘state’, foreign and defence policy, gender and international relations, and international institutions.

LING 350.description:
This course introduces the linguistic study of historical language change. The focus is on principles and method in the study
of phonological, morphological and syntactic change. Case studies will be drawn from a cross-section of languages,
including but not limited to members of the Indo-European language family.
LING 350.title: Introduction to Historical Linguistics
PREREQUISITE: LING 320/3.0 or permission of the Department of Languages, Literatures and Cultures.

POLS 320.description: An examination of First Nations politics in a Canadian context, including aboriginal self-government.
POLS 320.title: First Nations Politics
PREREQUISITE:
(12 units in POLS at the 200 level or above) and (a GPA of 2.0 on all units in POLS), or permission of the
Department.

MATH 406.description:
Construction and properties of finite fields. Polynomials, vector spaces, block codes over finite fields. Hamming distance
and other code parameters. Bounds relating code parameters. Cyclic codes and their structure as ideals. Weight
distribution. Special codes and their relation to designs and projective planes. Decoding algorithms.
MATH 406.title: Introduction to Coding Theory

EXCLUSION:
No more than 6.0 units from IDIS 150/6.0; KNPE 125/3.0; KNPE 225/3.0; PHGY 210/6.0; PHGY 214/6.0; PHGY
212/6.0.
PHGY 214.description: The function of organs, body systems, and the integration of functions in the whole body.
NOTE: Students in a KINE, HLTH; PHED or NURS Plan should not register in this course.
PHGY 214.title: Mammalian Physiology
PREREQUISITE: A minimum GPA of 2.0 in BIOL 102/3.0 and BIOL 103/3.0.

POLS 388.description:
Focusing on issues of citizenship and non-citizenship in the modern world. How issues of nationality and nationalism,
minority rights, gender, class, race and ethnicity, and immigration status impact on the rights and obligations of citizenship
and central to the politics of these debates. The relevance of these issues to the current Canadian context will be an
ongoing theme of the course.
POLS 388.title: Citizenship and Non-Citizenship
PREREQUISITE:
(12 units in POLS at the 200 level or above) and (a GPA of 2.0 on all units in POLS), or permission of the
Department.

CLST 100.description:
Ancient Greek and Roman literature in translation: Homer’s Iliad and Odyssey and Greek drama; Vergil’s Aeneid and
selections from other Latin authors. Reference to ancient customs, history, mythology, thought.
CLST 100.title: Introduction to Classical Literature

PHIL 348.description:
An examination of the concept of freedom of the will, with emphasis on the problems generated by causation and the
notion of responsibility.
PHIL 348.title: Freedom of the Will
PREREQUISITE: PHIL 250/6.0 or PHIL 257/6.0 or permission of the Department.

RELS 340.description:
Deals with the role of religion in the public sphere and its relation to liberal democracy. It examines the (in)compatibility of
some tenets of certain religions with modern democratic principles.
RELS 340.title: Religion and Democracy
PREREQUISITE: Level 3 or above or 6.0 units at the 100 level in RELS.

STAT 455.description:
Markov chains, birth and death processes, random walk problems, elementary renewal theory, Markov processes,
Brownian motion and Poisson processes, queuing theory, branching processes. Given jointly with STAT 855/3.0.
STAT 455.title: Stochastic Processes and Applications
PREREQUISITE: STAT 353/3.0 or (STAT 269/3.0 or STAT 351/3.0 with permission of the Department).

HIST 451.description:
he Experience of War in 20th Century Europe
An examination of transformations in the conception, practice and experience of war in 20th century Europe with a focus
on the two World Wars. Topics include international law, gender and the home-front, trench warfare, popular violence and
genocide, collaboration and resistance, and memory. Students will read primary sources such as diaries, letters and novels
as well as scholarly literature.
PREREQUISITE: A Grade of C+ in 6.0 units from HIST 300-329 and registration in a HIST Major or Medial Plan.

ENGL 335.description:
A study of English drama from the medieval to the Restoration period. Emphasis falls on tracing the development of
dramatic forms, traditions, and performance practices in relation to socio-cultural history.
ENGL 335.title: English Drama to 1700
PREREQUISITE:
(ENGL 200/6.0 and ENGL 290/3.0) and (a GPA of 2.4 on all ENGL units) and (registration in an ENGL Major
or Medial Plan).

EXCLUSION: No more than one course from FILM 370/3.0; FILM 375/6.0.
FILM 370.description:
Intermediate critical and historical study in the avant-garde of the international cinema, based on selected examples principally
from Europe, the United States and Canada.
FILM 370.title: The Experimental Tradition
PREREQUISITE: Registration in a FILM Plan, STSC or COCA Specialization and 12.0 units in FILM.

GRMN 101.description:
This course is for students with no previous knowledge of German. The course concentrates on the basic language skills
(listening, reading, writing and speaking) and introduces elements of German culture as recorded in its customs, history and
literature.
ONE-WAY EXCLUSION: May not be taken with or after GRMN 102/3.0; GRMN 201/3.0; GRMN 202/3.0.
GRMN 101.title: Beginner’s German I

BIOL 502.title: Plant Cellular Responses to Environmental Stress
PREREQUISITE:
Level 4 and registration in a Biology Honours Plan (BIOL-M-BSH, BIOL-P-BSH, BIMA-P-BSH, BIPS-P-BSH,
BTEC-P-BSH, EBIO-P-BSH) and a minimum GPA of 2.0 in the Biological Foundations List  and (BIOL 330/3.0 or BIOL 334/3.0
or BIOL 341/3.0 or BIOL 430/3.0) or permission of the Department.

EXCLUSION: No more than 3.0 units from APSC 142/3.0; CISC 101/3.0; CISC 110/3.0.
CISC 101.description:
Introduction to algorithms: their definition, design, coding, and execution on computers. Intended for students who have
no programming experience. All or most assignment work will be completed during lab time.
NOTE: Also offered online. Consult Arts and Science Online. Learning Hours may vary.
ONE-WAY EXCLUSION: May not be taken with or after: CISC 121/3.0; CISC; SOFT at the 200-level and above.
CISC 101.title: Elements of Computing Science

ARTH 228.description:
This course will examine the histories, meanings, and sites of contemporary art in the metropolitan West from the 1960’s to
the present. Students will become familiar not only with the works themselves, but with shifts in critical conceptions and
popular media that affect both the production and reception of contemporary art.
ARTH 228.title: Histories of Contemporary Art
PREREQUISITE: Level 2 or above or permission of the Department.

INTS 313.description:
This course will offer a unique opportunity to study a special topic in Modern European Studies. Topics will vary each term,
and the course may not be offered every year. For a detailed course description, see www.queensu.ca/bisc
NOTE: Offered only at the Bader International Study Centre, Herstmonceux.
INTS 313.title: Seminar in Modern European Studies II
PREREQUISITE: Level 2 or permission of the instructor.

CLST 214.description:
Ancient concepts of nature and of natural phenomena: what did the ancients (e.g. Babylonians and Greeks) know about the
natural world and how did they come to know it?
CLST 214.title: Ancient Science
PREREQUISITE: Level 2 or above.

FILM 422.description:
Advanced seminar on specific area of research and study selected by the instructor. Subjects have included Québécois
cinema, film and mass culture in Canada.
FILM 422.title: Canadian Cinema: Special Topic
PREREQUISITE:
Registration in a FILM Plan, STSC or COCA Specialization and 30.0 units in FILM or permission of the
Department.

EXCLUSION: No more than 6.0 units from PHYS 104/6.0, PHYS 106/6.0; PHYS 117/6.0; PHYS 118/6.0.
PHYS 118.description:
An algebra-based course dealing with basic Physics concepts, including dynamics, fluids, waves, electromagnetism, and
basic optics. Emphasis is placed on the development of problem-solving skills through the use of Mastery based course
delivery.
NOTE: Only offered online. Consult Arts and Science Online.
PHYS 118.title: Basic Physics

PHYS 454.description:
Groups of students in physics and engineering physics undertake a large design project of their choice that reflects and
further develops their knowledge of physics. The students then build a prototype of their design to demonstrate the
feasibility of the project within the design constraints.
PHYS 454.title: Advanced Physics Design Project

CRSS 456.description:
An intensive course surveying the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying the pathophysiology of the major
cardiovascular diseases, and the current and emerging tolls used in their diagnosis and treatment. Alterations in signalling,
metabolism, and structure and function will be discussed to present an integrative view of how cardiovascular diseases
develop and progress.
NOTE: Priority given to students in the CRSS Sub-Plan.
CRSS 456.title: Molecular and Cellular Basis of Cardiovascular Disease
PREREQUISITE:
Level 4 and registration in a LISC Major or Specialization Plan and a GPA of 2.5 and (PHGY 210/6.0 or PHGY
214/6.0 or PHGY 212/6.0).

SOCY 424.description:
This course provides a comprehensive and critical assessment of contemporary issues on social aging. This course focuses
on how society and its major institutions have reacted to the aging of society as well as how they have shaped it. The social-
psychological, social structural (gender, race and social class) and cultural factors that influence a person’s experience of
aging are examined.
SOCY 424.title: Sociology of Aging
PREREQUISITE:
Level 4 and registration in a SOCY Major or Medial Plan and (a minimum grade of C in SOCY 210/3.0 and
SOCY 211/3.0 and SOCY 226/3.0 and SOCY 227/3.0) and (a minimum GPA of 2.60 in SOCY 210/3.0 and SOCY 211/3.0 and
SOCY 226/3.0 and SOCY 227/3.0) and (a minimum GPA of 2.60 in all SOCY).

EXCLUSION: No more than 6.0 units from CHEM 112/6.0 or (CHEM 113/3.0 and CHEM 114/3.0).
CHEM 114.description:
A quantitative treatment of chemical phenomena and materials. Critical thinking and problem solving are emphasized.
Topics include atomic thermodynamics, chemical equilibria, acids and bases, kinetics, electrochemistry.
NOTE:
Only offered online. Consult Arts and Science Online.
Not appropriate for pre and upper level courses that have a laboratory component.
CHEM 114.title: General Chemistry II: Thermodynamic and Kinetics

EXCLUSION: No more than one course from FILM 368/3.0; FILM 385/6.0.
FILM 368.description:
A course on the history, theory, and practice of animated films. Requirements include a series of screenings, writings, and a
practice based critical project.
FILM 368.title: Animation Theory and Criticism
PREREQUISITE: Registration in a FILM Plan, STSC or COCA Specialization and 12.0 units in FILM.

GRMN 317.description:
This course's aim is threefold: to improve students' comprehension and production of oral and written German through practice
in reading, writing, listening and speaking; to increase their knowledge of contemporary issues in Germany, with a special focus on
transnational perspectives; and to better their analytic skills and media literacy.
GRMN 317.title: Contemporary Germany through Media and News
PREREQUISITE: A grade of C in GRMN 202/3.0 or permission of the Department of Languages, Literatures and Cultures.

PHIL 347.description:
A critical survey of some recent trends in moral philosophy. Study will begin with the emotive theory of ethics, and end with
very recent works of importance in the field.
PHIL 347.title: Contemporary Moral Philosophy
PREREQUISITE: PHIL 257/6.0 or permission of the Department.

EXCLUSION: No more than 3.0 units from WRIT 225/3.0; WRIT 195/3.0.
WRIT 225.description:
Offering modules on ten types of writing often encountered in various academic fields in university, this course allows
students to develop assignments based on the five most relevant to their program. Options range from reviews and lab
reports to position papers and annotated bibliographies, complemented by a Grammar and Mechanics Assessment.
NOTE: Offered only online. Consult Arts and Science Online.
WRIT 225.title: Writing in Academic Contexts

ENSC 501.description:
Independent Environmental Study
Independent study of an environmental topic by individuals or inter-disciplinary groups.
NOTE:
This course is intended for a self-motivated student with an established record of undergraduate performance, i.e.
cumulative GPA of approximately 3.0. It is the responsibility of the student to secure a supervisor prior to registering in the
course.
PREREQUISITE:
Open to students in the final year of an honours program in any discipline, and with permission of the
instructor of the course and of the Department of the student's Plan.

CISC 435.description:
Fundamental concepts in the design and implementation of computer communication networks, protocols, and
applications. Overview of network architectures; applications; network programming interfaces (e.g., sockets); transport;
congestion; routing and data link protocols; addressing; local area networks; wireless networks, mobility
management; security.
CISC 435.title: Computer Communications and Networks
PREREQUISITE: C- in CISC 324/3.0.

FREN 118.description:
This course is designed for students who have completed beginner level French. In this course students will further develop
their written and oral communication skills as well as acquire the means to competently engage in a range of everyday
common social and professional situations.
NOTE: Only offered online. Consult Arts and Science Online.
ONE-WAY EXCLUSION: May not be taken after FREN 150/6.0 or FREN 100/6.0.
FREN 118.title: Communication et culture III

EXCLUSION: No more than 3.0 units from ITLN 234/3.0; ITLN 332/3.0; LLCU 234/3.0.
ITLN 332.description: A survey of Italian literature, through selected texts of representative authors, from the eighteenth century to the present.
NOTE:
Taught in English together with LLCU 234/3.0. Students submit written assignments, tests, and examinations in
Italian.
ITLN 332.title: Survey of Italian Literature II

ENGL 421.description: For detailed information, consult the Department.
ENGL 421.title: Topics in Renaissance Literature I
PREREQUISITE:
(ENGL 200/6.0 and ENGL 290/3.0) and (a GPA of 2.4 on all ENGL units) and (registration in an ENGL Major
or Medial Plan).

BIOL 539.description:
Research practicum under the supervision of a Biology faculty member. The course will involve a combination of research in
the host laboratory, attendance of BIOL 537/12.0 or other seminars in the Department, and literature research to present
as a major paper and seminar.
NOTE:
Students will normally be enrolled in the fourth year of their Program, having completed the third year core
requirements of their Plan.
ONE-WAY EXCLUSION: Not to be taken concurrently with BIOL 537/12.0.
BIOL 539.title: Research Mentorship in Biology II
PREREQUISITE:
Registration in a Biology Honours Plan (BIOL-M-BSH, BIOL-P-BSH, BIMA-P-BSH, BIPS-P-BSH, EBIO-P-BSH)
and a minimum GPA of 2.0 in the Biological Foundations List and permission of the Department.
COREQUISITE    BIOL 538/3.0.

EXCLUSION: No more than 6.0 units from JAPN 300/6.0; JAPN 301/3.0; JAPN 302/3.0.
JAPN 302.description:
Intermediate study of the structural patterns of the language, with intensive training in listening, speaking, reading, and
writing. Extensive use of audio-visual materials.
NOTE: Students with previous study background must take a placement test during orientation week.
JAPN 302.title: Intermediate Japanese II
PREREQUISITE: A grade of C in JAPN 301/3.0 or permission of the Department of Languages, Literatures and Cultures.

HIST 431.description:
The political, social, cultural and economic development of the Maritimes and Newfoundland from the early 17th century
to the present.
HIST 431.title: tlantic Canada
PREREQUISITE: A Grade of C+ in 6.0 units from HIST 300-329 and registration in a HIST Major or Medial Plan.

PHIL 203.description:
Philosophical issues - both epistemological and ethical - involved in specific debates about the relationship between science
and social issues. The course may focus, for instance, on recent ‘popular’ sociobiology efforts by biologists and others to
establish scientific theories of human nature and human potential.
NOTE: Also offered online. Consult Arts and Science Online. Learning Hours may vary.
PHIL 203.title: Science and Society
PREREQUISITE: Level 2 or above or completed 6.0 units in PHIL.

KNPE 456.description:
Independent study involving a critical review of the literature on an approved topic of specialization in health
enhancement, disease prevention and human performance. Students must arrange for a faculty adviser approved by the
School of Kinesiology and Health Studies.
KNPE 456.title: Survey of Research and Literature in Kinesiology and Physical Education
PREREQUISITE:
Level 4 in a PHED Specialization or KINE Specialization Plan; permission of the supervisor and the
Undergraduate Coordinator.

ENGL 422.description: For detailed information, consult the Department.
ENGL 422.title: Topics in Renaissance Literature II
PREREQUISITE:
(ENGL 200/6.0 and ENGL 290/3.0) and (a GPA of 2.4 on all ENGL units) and (registration in an ENGL Major
or Medial Plan).

PSYC 471.description:
The neuropharmacological basis of psychological processes. Topics to be covered include drug actions on neurochemical
systems, psychoactive effects of drugs and the neuropharmacological basis of psychiatric disorders.
PSYC 471.title: Behavioural Pharmacology
PREREQUISITE: Level 3 and (PSYC 205/3.0 or [PSYC 271/3.0 and PSYC 370/3.0).

An intermediate study that examines how.code: An intermediate study that examines how performance shapes our social experiences and lived identities. From the daily
An intermediate study that examines how.description:
acts of self-performance on social media to mega events, performance binds contemporary cultural practices, small and
large.
NOTE:
Students will be required to attend a limited number of Kingston-based cultural productions over the course of the
term.
An intermediate study that examines how.title: Media and Performance
PREREQUISITE: Level 3 and registration in an ARTH, ARTV, DRAM, FILM, MUSC or STSC Plan.

PHGY 424.description:
The electrophysiology and biophysics of neuronal and cardiac membranes; molecular biology, structure, and function of ion
channels. Students will learn to critically evaluate scientific literature. Instructional format is primarily student-led seminars.
PHGY 424.title: Ion Channels of Excitable Cells
PREREQUISITE:
Level 4 and registration in a LISC Major or Specialization Plan and a GPA of 2.5 and (a minimum grade of C
in PHGY 210/6.0 or PHGY 214/6.0 or PHGY 212/6.0).

EXCLUSION: No more than 3.0 units from ITLN 210/3.0; ITLN 310/3.0; LLCU 210/3.0.
ITLN 310.description:
The ancient Greek and Roman tradition in literature, art and the politics of Italy from the Middle Ages to the 18th century.
Texts and works of art will be studied in the context of the historical, cultural and political settings of Italy.
NOTE:
Taught in English with LLCU 210/3.0. Students concentrating in Italian submit written assignments, tests and exams
in Italian. Normally students will read Italian texts in the original.
ITLN 310.title: Italy and the Classical Tradition

GEOL 466.description:
This course is designed to expose advanced students in the fields of biology, chemistry, geography or geology to the
principles of stable isotope and radiogenic isotope systematics in natural processes. Emphasis will be placed on the use of
isotopes in tracing elemental cycles, biological cycles and hydrologic cycles and how some isotopes can be used to place
constraints on the timing of specific events in these cycles.
NOTE: This course may not be offered every year. Consult : http://www.queensu.ca/geol/courses for more information
GEOL 466.title: Isotopes and the Environment
PREREQUISITE: CHEM 112 or permission of the Department.

HIST 269.description:
How political power was conceived, exercised, and contested in the aboriginal, French and British colonial, and early-
national formations in what is now Canada. The origins and nature of liberal democracy and changing forms of popular
political participation, schooling, and the criminal law receive particular attention.
HIST 269.title: olitics and the State in Canada to 1896
PREREQUISITE: Level 2 or above.

FREN 342.description:
An intro. to French 19th Century and contemporary literature. More specifically focused on literature the course will also
explore predominant trends in different media such as painting and cinema. Drawing on critical, historical, and literary
theory, students will acquire the skills to assess how specific works reflect or relate to the aesthetic, literary, and
philosophical trends of their time.
FREN 342.title: Histoire culturelle et littéraire de la France moderne et contemporaine
PREREQUISITE: (FREN 230/3.0 and FREN 241/3.0) or (FREN 212/6.0 and FREN 220/6.0) or FREN 221/6.0.

CWRI 293.description:
Creative Writing in Prose
A workshop course focusing on the writing and editing of short fiction, novels, and memoir. Students attempt several
different approaches to the writing of creative prose, as well as the process of publication in both magazine and book
formats.
NOTE: Admission is based on writing samples.
PREREQUISITE: Permission of the instructor.

POLS 313.description:
A critical examination of the relationship between the mass media and politics, focusing on the functions of the media in
modern liberal democracies and the ways in which news stories are created and packaged.
POLS 313.title: Mass Media and Politics in Canada
PREREQUISITE:
(12 units in POLS at the 200 level or above) and (a GPA of 2.0 on all units in POLS), or permission of the
Department.

EXCLUSION: No more than one course from MUSC 104/3.0; MUSC P06/0.0; MUSC P52/3.0.
MUSC 104.description: An introduction to musical notation, ear training, theory and analysis.
NOTE:
Students who hold Royal Conservatory Advanced Rudiments or higher should consult with the School for
appropriate course placement. May not be taken for credit by students in the B.Mus. Plan.
MUSC 104.title: Introduction to Music Fundamentals

HIST 208.description:
An interdisciplinary course in which the Canadian nation state will be examined from a geographic, historical, political,
cultural and economic perspective, with particular attention being paid to the First Nations and linguistic minorities.
HIST 208.title: ntroduction to Themes in Canadian History I
PREREQUISITE: Level 2 or above.

GREK 321.description:
Selected passages of Greek prose, usually drawn from oratory, history, and philosophy, read in the original Greek and
commented upon for their linguistic, literary, and historical significance.
NOTE: This course is normally co-taught with GREK 421/3.0.
GREK 321.title: Greek Prose
PREREQUISITE: A grade of C in GREK 208/6.0 or permission of the Department of Classics.

PATH 499.description:
A research project involving the study of human disease processes. The project will be supervised by a Faculty member in
the Department and will provide opportunities for experimental design, data analysis and both written and oral
presentation of results. Students must contact a potential faculty supervisor in the Spring preceding registration in fourth
year.
NOTE: Acceptance by a supervisor required prior to registration.
PATH 499.title: Research Project in Pathology
PREREQUISITE: Level 4 and registration in a LISC Specialization Plan and a GPA of 2.50.

EXCLUSION: May not be taken with or after PHIL 247/3.0.
PHIL 301.description:
Bioethics
An investigation of some moral issues arising in connection with health care, including: the relationship between patient
and health care provider; reproductive decision-making; euthanasia and the nature of death; and the development of
health care policy.
PREREQUISITE: Level 3 or above.

HIST 255.description:
A survey of the social, cultural, political and intellectual life of Europe in the Renaissance and Reformation. Topics to be
discussed include: humanism, secularism, printing, and exploration; war and the early modern state; prophecy, heresy, and
dissent; popular culture; sex, marriage, and family life; witch hunts, panics, and magic; and the impact of the Reformation
and the Counter Reformation.
HIST 255.title: enaissance and Reformation Europe
PREREQUISITE: Level 2 or above.

PHYS 345.description:
Spin. Addition of angular momentum. Many electron atoms and the periodic table. Introduction to perturbation theory and
Fermi’s golden rule. Time dependent perturbations, including stimulated emission. Introduction to nuclear and particle
physics.
PHYS 345.title: Quantum Physics of Atoms, Nuclei and Particles

EXCLUSION: No more than 1 course from ARTF 101/3.0; ARTF 105/6.0; ARTF 106/3.0; ARTF 127/6.0.
RECOMMENDATION:
ARTH 120/6.0. A survey course in Art History provides increased visual literacy at the studio level.
Previous experience in painting and drawing is highly recommended.
ARTF 101.description:
A foundation course aimed at developing basic skills in drawing and painting, embracing a variety of subjects, materials and
techniques.
NOTE: Materials: estimated cost $300.
ARTF 101.title: Fundamentals of Drawing and Painting
PREREQUISITE: Permission of the instructor.

ARTH 435.description:
This course examines a range of theoretical approaches used currently in art historical scholarship, including Marxism,
gender theory, psychoanalysis, structuralism, poststructuralism, and postcolonialism.
ARTH 435.title: Art History Theory and Methods
PREREQUISITE:
A GPA of 2.60 in a minimum of 24.0 units in ARTH courses and Level 4 and registration in an ARTH Major or
Medial Plan.

ENGL 292.title: Introduction to Literary Criticism and Theory

MUSC 398.description:
Modal Counterpoint
Study, through rule-based writing, of 16th century modal counterpoint, from two-part species exercises to free
counterpoint in Renaissance style.
PREREQUISITE: MUSC 293/3.0 or MUSC 291/6.0 or permission of the School.

EXCLUSION: No more than 3.0 units from LLCU 329/3.0; GRMN 429/3.0; ENGL 273/3.0.
LLCU 329.description:
This course offers an overview of the related genres of the Fantastic, the Fairy Tale, Dystopia, Science Fiction, and Horror.
Examples will include popular works such as the Twilight Saga, Harry Potter, and/or The Hunger Games, but also traditional
texts by Hoffman and Kafka. Parallel to the fictional works, the course offers theoretical analysis.
LLCU 329.title: Uncanny Encounters: Narrative Analysis of the Fantastic Genre
PREREQUISITE: Level 3 or permission of the Department of Languages, Literatures and Cultures.

ARTH 410.description: Studies in the textiles and dress of selected periods with a focus upon visual culture and/or material culture.
ARTH 410.title: Studies in the History of Textiles and Dress
PREREQUISITE:
A GPA of 2.60 in a minimum of 24.0 units in ARTH courses and Level 4 and registration in an ARTH Major or
Medial Plan.

KNPE 251.description:
An introduction to the analysis of data from real life situations. Covers study design, descriptive and inferential statistics.
Topics include probability, t-tests, regression, Chi-square tests, analysis of variance. Emphasis is in the foundation of
statistical inference and practical application of statistical methods using statistical software.
KNPE 251.title: Introduction to Statistics
PREREQUISITE: Level 2 or above in a PHED, KINE or HLTH plan.

ENGL 235.description:
Life writing includes autobiography, biography, diaries, letters, and memoirs. The aim of this course will be to explore its
generic conventions and innovations, to consider the interplay between lived experience and its textual representation, and
to examine the social and cultural dimensions of life stories.
ENGL 235.title: Life Writing
PREREQUISITE: A grade of C in ENGL 100/6.0.

RELS 328.description:
The primary focus of the course will be the theological perspectives and social functions of apocalyptic in select religious
traditions. The course will also survey the appropriation of apocalyptic themes throughout history in artistic forms such as
art, fiction, and film, with particular attention to our modern times and cultures.
RELS 328.title: Interpretation of Apocalyptic Literature
PREREQUISITE: Level 3 or above or 6.0 units at the 100 level in RELS.

RELS 237.description:
How religion is portrayed in film; particularly the depiction of religious belief, practices, practitioners, and institutions, and the
use of religious symbols and metaphors.
RELS 237.title: Religion and Film
PREREQUISITE: Level 2 or above or 6.0 units at the 100 level in RELS.

ECON 231.description:
An examination of the origins of modern economic growth concentrating on the industrial revolution in Britain and the
prior developments leading up to it. Some attention is directed to the early followers of the changes initiated in Britain.
ECON 231.title: Emergence of the Modern Industrial Economy
PREREQUISITE: ECON 110/6.0 or ECON 111/3.0.

BIOL 439.description:
The mechanisms of evolutionary change - from genes to societies. How natural selection interacts with genetic and
population processes to make organisms adapted to their environment and to create biological diversity.
BIOL 439.title: Natural Selection and Microevolution
PREREQUISITE: (BIOL 302/3.0 or BIOL 303/3.0) and a minimum GPA of 2.0 in the Biological Foundations List.

EXCLUSION: No more than one course from HIST 286/3.0; HIST 315/6.0.
HIST 286.description:
A survey of Latin American history from 1850 to the recent past. Major events of the 20th century will be examined in
historical context, with special attention to issues of development, nation building, and political and social conflict.
HIST 286.title: atin America from 1850 to Today: The Modern Era
PREREQUISITE: Level 2 or above.

KNPE 237.description:
This course is an exploration of behavioural and biological research on physical activity and how it relates to the
psychosocial, structural, and physiological development of children between birth and approximately age 13.
KNPE 237.title: Child and Adolescent Motor Development
PREREQUISITE: Level 2 or above in a PHED or KINE Plan.

ENGL 306.description:
A survey of major literary works written in Old English and Old Norse from the ninth to the thirteenth centuries. Readings
will include sagas, epics, elegies, riddles, mythology, as well as historical and religious writing. Texts will be read in
translation.
ENGL 306.title: The Northern World: Vikings and Saxons
PREREQUISITE:
[(ENGL 200/6.0 and ENGL 290/3.0) and (a GPA of 2.4 on all ENGL units)] or [(a GPA of 2.6) and (registration
in a MDVL Plan)].

MUTH 240.description:
With so many digital disruptions and new intermediaries affecting the way creative works are conceived, created,
distributed, and consumed, this course explores a range of impacts on the entertainment sector, inspired by the Internet,
digital convergence, and mass adoption of mobile and social consumer technologies.
MUTH 240.title: Digital Disruption in the Creative and Performing Arts

PHIL 307.description: Specific topics in or traditions within Latin American and Caribbean Philosophy.
PHIL 307.title: Latin American and Caribbean Philosophy
PREREQUISITE: Level 3 and 12.0 units in PHIL, ENGL, HIST, or POLS.

ITLN 502.description:
Reading courses in specialized themes of Italian literature to meet the needs of advanced students for whom a seminar course
is not available. Course details to be announced on website.
ITLN 502.title: Letteratura italiana: Studi indipendenti
PREREQUISITE: Permission of the Department of Languagues, Literatures and Cultures.

EXCLUSION:
No more than 3.0 units from LLCU 210/3.0; ITLN 210/3.0; ITLN 310/3.0.
EQUIVALENCY    ITLN 210/3.0.
LLCU 210.description:
The ancient Greek and Roman tradition in literature, art and the politics of Italy from the Middle Ages to the 18th century.
Texts and works of art will be studied in the context of the historical, cultural and political settings of Italy.
LLCU 210.title: Italy and the Classical Tradition
PREREQUISITE: Level 2 or permission of the Department of Languages, Literatures and Cultures.

EXCLUSION: No more than 3.0 units from CISC 437/3.0; SOFT 437/3.0.
SOFT 437.title: Performance Analysis
PREREQUISITE: CISC 324/3.0 and CISC 327/3.0.

STAT 473.description:
An introduction to advanced regression methods for binary, categorical, and count data. Major topics include maximum-
likelihood method, binomial and Poisson regression, contingency tables, log linear models, and random effect models. The
generalized linear models will be discussed both in theory and in applications to real data from a variety of sources. Given
jointly with STAT 873/3.0.
STAT 473.title: Generalized Linear Models
PREREQUISITE: (STAT 361/3.0 or ECON 351/3.0) and STAT 463/3.0 or permission of the Department.

GPHY 257.description:
The lands and peoples of Mexico, Central America, and the West Indies, emphasizing the historical factors that shape
contemporary life in the region.
GPHY 257.title: The Geography of Middle America
PREREQUISITE: Level 2 or above or permission of the Department.

Fundamental properties of the nervous sy.code: Fundamental properties of the nervous system. Emphasis placed on the properties of neurons that are fundamental to
Fundamental properties of the nervous sy.description:
neuron-to-neuron communication, the formation of neural circuits, and the repair of the nervous system following injury.
Tutorials introduce techniques and neurological problems that illustrate principles of neural function.
Fundamental properties of the nervous sy.title: Cellular Neuroscience
PREREQUISITE: PHGY 210/6.0 or PHGY 214/6.0 or BIOL 339/3.0 or PSYC 271/3.0 or PHGY 212/6.0.

HLTH 595.description:
An independent study involving a research proposal and project on an approved topic in the area of health enhancement or
disease prevention. The research proposal will be completed in the fall term and the research project in the winter term.
Students must arrange for a full-time faculty advisor in the School of Kinesiology and Health Studies.
NOTE: Limited spaces available; priority to Health Studies students.
HLTH 595.title: Honours Thesis in Health Studies
PREREQUISITE:
A GPA of 3.50 and level 4 in a PHED Specialization, KINE Specialization or (HLTH Major or Medial) Plan;
permission of the supervisor and Undergraduate Coordinator in the School of Kinesiology and Health Studies.

ENGL 389.description:
A study of modern and/or contemporary North American literatures (which may include some works in translation).
Content will vary, but the aim will be to discern how cultural similarities and differences are reflected in individual works by
writers from (e.g.) Canada, the United States, and the Caribbean.
ENGL 389.title: Context North America
PREREQUISITE:
(ENGL 200/6.0 and ENGL 290/3.0) and (a GPA of 2.4 on all ENGL units) and (registration in an ENGL Major
or Medial Plan).

EXCLUSION: No more than 3.0 units from FREN 315/3.0; FREN 405/3.0.
FREN 315.description:
A study of representative literary works of the 15th and 16th centuries, including Villon, Montaigne, Rabelais. Travaux pratiques
include essays and tests.
FREN 315.title: Littérature française de la Renaissance
PREREQUISITE: (FREN 230/3.0 and FREN 241/3.0) or (FREN 212/6.0 and FREN 220/6.0) or FREN 221/6.0.

ARTH 401.description:
The study of a selected theme within the subject matter of Western art, concentrating on its changing modes of
representation in response to historical and artistic circumstances.
ARTH 401.title: Studies in Iconography
PREREQUISITE:
A GPA of 2.60 in a minimum of 24.0 units in ARTH courses and Level 4 and registration in an ARTH Major or
Medial Plan.

ARTH 301.description: A study of selected objects with a focus on materials and meanings.
ARTH 301.title: The Artwork as Material Object
PREREQUISITE: Level 3 or above.

EXCLUSION: No more than 1 course from HIST 263/3.0; HIST 322/6.0.
HIST 263.description:
A blended online/classroom course that will introduce students to armed forces in modern history, and how they relate to
the societies they function within and against.
NOTE: Also offered online. Consult Arts and Science Online. Learning Hours may vary.
HIST 263.title: ar in the Twentieth Century: Myths and Reality
PREREQUISITE: Level 2 or above.

EXCLUSION: No more than 3.0 units from CISC 426/3.0; SOFT 426/3.0.
SOFT 426.title: Real-Time Systems
PREREQUISITE: CISC 324/3.0 and CISC 327/3.0.

PHIL 510.description:
This course involves a directed study of a philosophical topic. Topics chosen may be from any area of philosophy, and
should be determined in consultation with a proposed supervising instructor.
PHIL 510.title: Directed Special Studies
PREREQUISITE:
Level 4 and registration in a PHIL Major or Medial Plan and (a minimum GPA of 2.60 in PHIL 250/6.0 and
PHIL 257/6.0) and permission of the Department.

CLST 411.description:
Topics in Greek Scholarship II
Intensive study of a special topic, period, or author(s) in the Greek world.
PREREQUISITE: Level 4 in a CLST or CLAS or GREK or LATN Plan, and permission of Department.

POLS 590.description:
Thesis
The thesis is optional and counts as one course toward an honours concentration in Political Studies. The thesis subject
must be selected at the end of the penultimate year after consultation with members of the Department, and the thesis
must be submitted by 31 March of the final year. The student can choose to pay for binding of the departmental copy.
PREREQUISITE:
Level 4 and (registration in a POLS Major or Medial Plan) and POLS 250/6.0 and (a GPA of 2.9 on all units in
POLS).

INTS 323.description:
A study of thematic and stylistic approaches to the representation of selected cultures and to the presentation and
evocation of global issues in one or more of the fine, performing or media arts. Topics will vary each year. For detailed
course description, see www.queensu.ca/bisc
NOTE: Offered only at the Bader International Study Centre, Herstmonceux.
INTS 323.title: International Perspectives in the Creative Arts I
PREREQUISITE: Level 2 in the relevant arts discipline.

MATH 414.description: An introduction to Galois Theory and some of its applications.
MATH 414.title: Introduction to Galois Theory

ENGL 437.description:
Studies in literary topics focused on the period before 1800 that do not fit within the established Group I rubrics (Medieval,
Renaissance, Restoration/18th Century). For detailed information, consult the Department.
ENGL 437.title: Group I: Special Topics II
PREREQUISITE:
(ENGL 200/6.0 and ENGL 290/3.0) and (a GPA of 2.4 on all ENGL units) and (registration in an ENGL Major
or Medial Plan).

CLST 312.description:
Greek and Roman Drama
Intensive study (in translation) of representative works from the ancient theatre, both tragic (Aeschylus, Sophocles,
Euripides, Seneca) and comic (Aristophanes, Menander, Plautus, Terence). Comparative study of English drama of the
classical tradition encouraged.
PREREQUISITE:
CLST 100/6.0 or (CLST 102/3.0 and CLST 103/3.0) or DRAM 200/6.0 or DRAM 219/3.0 or CLST 101/6.0 or
DRAM 210/6.0 or permission of the Department.

ARTF 338.description:
In this second advanced-level course students choose two media sections from these areas: paint, media, sculpture/new
media, or print media. The media area chosen must be different from that studied in ARTF 337/9.0. The course will include
seminars introducing elements of professional practice.
NOTE: Open only to students in a BFA Program.
ARTF 338.title: Advanced Programs II
PREREQUISITE: A minimum grade of C- in ARTF 337/9.0 and a GPA of 1.60.

ENGL 432.description: For detailed information, consult the Department.
ENGL 432.title: Topics in Restoration and 18th-Century Literature II
PREREQUISITE:
(ENGL 200/6.0 and ENGL 290/3.0) and (a GPA of 2.4 on all ENGL units) and (registration in an ENGL Major
or Medial Plan).

RELS 255.description: An investigation into the techniques of critical reading and writing for research in Religious Studies.
RELS 255.title: Research Methods in Religious Studies
PREREQUISITE: Level 2 or above or 6.0 units at the 100 level in RELS.

BIOL 530.title: Origins of Biodiversity
PREREQUISITE:
Level 4 and registration in a Biology Honours Plan (BIOL-M-BSH, BIOL-P-BSH, BIMA-P-BSH, BIPS-P-BSH,
BTEC-P-BSH, EBIO-P-BSH) and a minimum GPA of 2.0 in the Biological Foundations List or permission of the Department.

EXCLUSION: No more than 1 course from DEVS 410/6.0; DEVS 420/3.0; DEVS 432/6.0.
DEVS 420.description:
Participation in an organized educational or cultural exchange, either i) one term of studies at a developing-country
university, or ii) an exchange program in a developing-country setting with an organization such as Canada World Youth or
Shastri Indo-Canadian Institute for at least 6 weeks. Students are required to prepare a work-study proposal, a risk
assessment of their placement and attend a pre-departure orientation. Assessment will also be based on a journal and final
report.
NOTE: Students are normally responsible for all costs associated with this course.
DEVS 420.title: Study Placement in Development Studies
PREREQUISITE:
Level 3 or above and registration in the DEVS Major or Medial Plan and departmental approval in advance
from the Placement Coordinator, Global Development Studies.

KNPE 254.description:
Students will learn to apply the knowledge and skills acquired in KNPE 153 to conduct detailed analyses of human
movement including how to analyze human movement using information obtained from different measurement tools.
Examples will be used to demonstrate how biomechanics can be used to enhance and maintain human health, fitness and
performance.
KNPE 254.title: Biomechanical Analysis of Human Movement
PREREQUISITE: Level 2 or above in a PHED or KINE Plan and KNPE 153/3.0.

PHIL 361.description:
From propositional calculus to first-order monadic predicate calculus. Symbolization, rules of inference, derivation and
refutation of arguments.
ONE-WAY EXCLUSION: May not be taken with or after: CISC 204/3.0.
PHIL 361.title: Introduction to Logic
PREREQUISITE: A GPA of 2.0 in 6.0 units in PHIL.

PHIL 257.description: A study of problems in moral and/or political philosophy from the ancient or early modern period to the present.
PHIL 257.title: Ethics
PREREQUISITE: A GPA of 2.0 in 6.0 units in PHIL.

BIOL 319.description:
Ethnobotany is the study of the relationships that exist between indigenous cultures and local flora. Case studies will be
presented to examine the various categories of plant use, the importance of traditional knowledge to Western culture, and
the role of plant conservation and cultural sustainability.
NOTE: Only offered online. Consult Arts and Science Online.
BIOL 319.title: Introduction to Ethnobotany
PREREQUISITE: BIOL 102/3.0 and BIOL 103/3.0.

WRIT 120.description:
Fundamentals of Effective Writing
A focus on the principles and practical applications of effective writing. Students apply effective writing strategies to
address a variety of professional and academic audiences. Students plan, outline, write, and revise reader-centred
documents that relate to forms and contexts they will encounter in the workplace and in educational environments.
NOTE: Only offered online. Consult Arts and Science Online.

COMP 392.description:
A Computing Internship involves spending twelve to sixteen months in a paid internship position in the private or public
sectors. Students in a 12-month internship register in COMP 390/6.0 and either COMP 391/3.0 or COMP 392/3.0, or all of
COMP 393/3.0, COMP 391/3.0 and COMP 392/3.0. Students in a 16-month internship register in COMP 390/6.0, COMP
391/3.0 and COMP 392/3.0. The Internship Coordinator must be satisfied that the work carried out has educational merit.
Successful completion of the course requires submission of a satisfactory report on the experience within thirty days of
completion of the work period. The Internship Coordinator is responsible for evaluating the report. The QUIP program
includes prior workshops on interviewing, resumé preparation and work performance. Career Services manages the non-
academic aspects of the program.
COMP 392.title: Computing Internship III
PREREQUISITE:
GPA of 1.90 and Level 2 or 3 and registration in a Bachelor of Computing internship plan (BMCO-I-BCH or
COGS-I-BCH or COMP-I-BCH or CSCI-I-BCH or SODE-I-BCH).

ENGL 420.description:
Studies in Renaissance Literature
For detailed information, consult the Department.
PREREQUISITE:
(ENGL 200/6.0 and ENGL 290/3.0) and (a GPA of 2.4 on all ENGL units) and (registration in an ENGL Major
or Medial Plan).

SPAN 306.description:
A study of selected works by Spanish American writers such as Horacio Quiroga, Gabriel García Márquez, Jorge Luis Borges,
Juan Rulfo, Julio Cortázar and Reinaldo Arenas.
SPAN 306.title: La narrativa hispanoamericana del siglo 20
PREREQUISITE:
SPAN 352/3.0.
COREQUISITE    (SPAN 301/3.0 and SPAN 302/3.0) or (SPAN 303/3.0 and SPAN 304/3.0).

MUSC 399.description:
Study, through composition, of the contrapuntal procedures of the 18th century, with an emphasis on J.S. Bach’s two-part
inventions and fugues.
MUSC 399.title: Tonal Counterpoint
PREREQUISITE: MUSC 293/3.0 or MUSC 291/6.0 or permission of the School.

EXCLUSION: No more than 6.0 units from HIST 289/3.0; HIST 329/6.0.
HIST 289.description: A survey of British history in the 19th and 20th centuries.
HIST 289.title: ritain since 1851
PREREQUISITE: Level 2 or above.

BIOL 341.description:
The course examines various aspects of plant cell biology, physiology, and biochemistry including carbon and nitrogen
metabolism (photosynthesis, respiration, etc.), water relations, mineral nutrition, response to environmental stress, roles of
plant hormones, plant biotechnology.
BIOL 341.title: Plant Physiology
PREREQUISITE: BIOL 205/3.0 or BCHM 218/3.0.

DRAM 289.description:
An examination of the theatrical nature of British and European dramatic literature, current and past productions, and
architectural structures, using various elements of site and performance as text for discussion and projects.
NOTE: Offered only at the Bader International Study Centre, Herstmonceux.
DRAM 289.title: Special Studies in British and European Theatre

EXCLUSION:
No more than 6.0 units from IDIS 150/6.0; KNPE 125/3.0; KNPE 225/3.0; PHGY 210/6.0; PHGY 214/6.0; PHGY
212/6.0.
PHGY 210.description: The function of organs, body systems and the integration of functions in the whole body.
NOTE: Only offered online. Consult Arts and Science Online.
PHGY 210.title: Physiology for Health Sciences
PREREQUISITE:
Level 2 and [a GPA of 2.0 in (BIOL 102/3.0 and BIOL 103/3.0) or PHGY 170/3.0] or permission of the
instructor.

BIOL 422.description:
The application of biological research to the conservation of biodiversity and natural resources, as well as the interaction of
biology with philosophy, politics and economics in influencing conservation policy.
BIOL 422.title: Conservation Biology
PREREQUISITE: (BIOL 302/3.0 or BIOL 303/3.0) and a minimum GPA of 2.0 in the Biological Foundations List.

EXCLUSION: No more than 3.0 units from LLCU 332/3.0; SPAN 332/3.0.
SPAN 332.description:
Spanish Baroque Short Theatre
Short theatre played an important role in the theatre of Spanish Golden Age. In this course students will study the literary
particularities of the genre and the social ramifications of the themes present in short theatre (gender, battle of the sexes,
diversity, authority amongst others) and their historical and contemporary relevance.
NOTE: Taught in English with LLCU 332/3.0. Written work and examinations are in Spanish. Readings are in translation.
PREREQUISITE: SPAN 380/3.0 or SPAN 381/3.0.

MUSC 415.description:
Large ensemble for qualified instrumentalists and singers. Topics vary. Course includes weekly rehearsals of a wide variety
of repertoire, and a minimum of one concert per term, for all students. Credit attained only with regular attendance, active
participation, and ample preparation.
MUSC 415.title: Large Ensemble
PREREQUISITE: Permission of the School upon audition.

As insight regarding the human brain exp.code: As insight regarding the human brain expands, so do related issues such as what constitutes personhood, what drives the
As insight regarding the human brain exp.description:
criminal mind, intelligence-enhancing drugs and end-of-life issues. Lead by experts who deal daily with such concerns, we
will focus weekly on a particular topic in neuroscience which impacts on society.
As insight regarding the human brain exp.title: Controversies in Neuroscience
PREREQUISITE:
Level 4 and registration in a LISC Major or Specialization Plan and a GPA of 2.5 and (ANAT 312/3.0 or NSCI
323/3.0 or NSCI 324/3.0 or PSYC 271/3.0).

EXCLUSION: No more than 3.0 units from LLCU 316/3.0; SPAN 316/3.0; SPAN 406/3.0
SPAN 406.description:
An introduction to contemporary literary theories and the analysis of Hispanic texts from reader-, structural- and author-
oriented perspectives.
NOTE:
Taught in English together with LLCU 316/3.0. Students concentrating in Spanish submit written assignments, tests,
and examination in Spanish. Normally they will read Hispanic texts in the original.
SPAN 406.title: Introducción a la teoría y el análisis literario
PREREQUISITE: SPAN 352/3.0 (or permission of the Department of Languages, Literatures and Cultures).

ENGL 365.description: A study of poetry from the twentieth and twenty-first centuries.
ENGL 365.title: Modern and Contemporary Poetry
PREREQUISITE:
(ENGL 200/6.0 and ENGL 290/3.0) and (a GPA of 2.4 on all ENGL units) and (registration in an ENGL Major
or Medial Plan).

EXCLUSION: No more than 1 course from MATH 334/3.0; MATH 338/3.0; PHYS 316/3.0; PHYS 312/6.0.
PHYS 316.description:
Methods of mathematics important for physicists. Complex arithmetic, series expansions and approximations of functions,
Fourier series and transforms, vector spaces and eigenvalue problems, ordinary differential equations and Green’s
functions.
PHYS 316.title: Methods in Mathematical Physics I
PREREQUISITE:
(MATH 221/3.0 or MATH 280/3.0 or MATH 227/3.0) and (MATH 225/3.0 or MATH 231/3.0 or MATH
232/3.0).

PSYC 437.description:
An intensive study of the state of research and controversies in the area of mood disorders. Specific topics covered will
include bio-genetic, cognitive, interpersonal, and stress theories of etiology, as well as state-of-the-art advances in
treatment.
PSYC 437.title: Mood Disorders
PREREQUISITE: PSYC 203/3.0 and (PSYC 235/6.0 or PSYC 236/3.0).

KNPE 203.description:
This course provides an introduction to theoretical and methodological research on coaching, with a special emphasis on
the influence of coaches’ interpersonal knowledge/behaviours on athlete development. Concepts related to leadership,
coach behaviours, and coach education will be explored.
KNPE 203.title: The Art and Science of Coaching
PREREQUISITE: Level 2 or above in a PHED or KINE Plan and KNPE 265/3.0.

SOCY 304.description:
Explores a range of contemporary issues in communications and information technology. Topics may vary from year to
year. See the departmental website for further details.
SOCY 304.title: Selected Topics in Communications and Information Technology
PREREQUISITE: A grade of C- in SOCY 122/6.0 or (BISC 100/3.0 and BISC 101/3.0).

KNPE 363.description:
An integration of theory, research and applied work in the area of applied sport psychology. Analysis, discussion of
theoretical issues related to performance and practical application of mental skills such as arousal management, attention
control, decision making, goal setting, positive self-talk, and time management.
KNPE 363.title: Psychology of Sport and Performance
PREREQUISITE: Level 3 or above in a PHED or KINE Plan and KNPE 265/3.0.

RELS 218.description: Introduction to Christianity as a religious tradition through its texts, its history and its contemporary forms.
RELS 218.title: Christianity
PREREQUISITE: Level 2 or above or 6.0 units at the 100 level in RELS.

LING 202.description:
This course investigates the distinctive characteristics of Canadian English as it is spoken and written today. Topics include
historical development, regional dialects, and current changes. Students will have access to the extensive bibliographic and
computer corpus resources of the Strathy Language Unit.
LING 202.title: Canadian English

HLTH 305.description:
An overview of the fundamentals of health policy with an emphasis on the Canadian context. Topics to be discussed include
history of the Canadian public health care system; the Canada Health Act; the political and economic environment of the
Canadian health care system; issue and challenges in Canadian health policy; and comparative perspectives.
HLTH 305.title: Fundamentals of Health Policy
PREREQUISITE: Level 3 or above and HLTH 101/3.0.

ENGL 277.description:
This course will explore how different literary works represent desire, romance, queerness, and other gender-related
issues. Particular focus may vary from year to year; for detailed information, consult the Department.
ENGL 277.title: Literature and Gender
PREREQUISITE: A grade of C in ENGL 100/6.0 or (registration in a GNDS Plan).

CHIN 200.description:
For students with some knowledge of Cantonese who wish to acquire a command of Mandarin or for students with some
knowledge of Mandarin who want to improve their Chinese language skills. Continued study of basic structural patterns of
the language with the emphasis on oral communication, reading and writing using the simplified forms of Chinese
characters.
NOTE: Students will have their level of competence assessed by the instructor during orientation week in September.
CHIN 200.title: Introductory Mandarin Chinese II
PREREQUISITE: CHIN 100/6.0 and permission of the Department of Languages, Literatures and Cultures.

MUTH 201.description:
This course is structured around a series of case studies of particular moments in the history of the representation of sex
and violence in dramatic and musical performances.
NOTE: Only offered online. Consult Arts and Science Online.
MUTH 201.title: Sex and Violence in Performance
PREREQUISITE: Level 2.

WRIT 275.description:
An interdisciplinary course on analytical writing, applying selected principles of rhetoric and linguistics. Collaborative
exercises and peer-edited essays are supplemented by critical reading of diverse articles and narratives. Enrolment is
limited.
WRIT 275.title: Analytical Writing
PREREQUISITE: WRIT 175/3.0 or permission of the instructor.

FILM 500.description:
Open to students completing an honours concentration in Film and Media, or Stage and Screen Studies. May be an essay or
a film or video project. Apply for FILM 500/6.0 or FILM 501/3.0, but not both, to the Undergraduate Coordinator by end of
Level 3.
NOTE: To use Film and Media video equipment the student must have completed FILM 250/6.0.
FILM 500.title: Honours Thesis
PREREQUISITE:
Registration in a FILM Major or Medial Plan, STSC or COCA Specialization and 30.0 units in FILM or
permission of the Department.

HIST 211.description:
This course will explore the origins of the struggle between the postwar superpowers, the United States and the Soviet
Union; the changing nature of their rivalry, and the way other nations were drawn into the conflict. It considers the Cold
War from Western, Soviet, and various global perspectives.
NOTE: Also offered online. Consult Arts and Science Online.
HIST 211.title: he Cold War
PREREQUISITE: Level 2 or above.

PACT 338.description:
Theory and practice of warm weather camping and canoe tripping. Students spend one pre-term week learning a variety of
camping and canoeing skills and application on an extended canoe trip.
NOTE: The Camp School Aquatic Test is also required to register in this course.
PACT 338.title: Outdoor Education
PREREQUISITE: Level 3 or 4 in a PHED Specialization Plan and PACT P01/0.0.

ECON 445.description:
An analysis of industry structure, conduct and performance in the Canadian economy, including the major features and
current issues of competition policy.
ECON 445.title: Industrial Organization and Public Policy

MUSC 388.description: A study of art music in Canada since 1930 with an emphasis on specific composers and their works.
MUSC 388.title: Canadian Music Since 1930
PREREQUISITE:
MUSC 103/3.0 and (MUSC 203/3.0 or MUSC 204/3.0 or MUSC 205/3.0).
COREQUISITE    MUSC 293/3.0 or MUSC 291/3.0 or permission of the School.

DEVS 250.description:
Examines the relationship between development and environmental change by introducing social science perspectives on
themes including energy, agriculture, climate, urbanization, and water. With a focus on combining macro- and micro-
analysis, the course reflects on the meaning of development in an era of global environmental transformation.
DEVS 250.title: Global Environmental Transformations
PREREQUISITE: Level 2 or above.

DRAM 545.description:
Directed Special Studies in Technical Production
Advanced examination of various roles in technical production, especially production and stage management, over the full
year. Practical stage management projects are a component of the course.
NOTE: The normal classroom time of 36 hours is spread over two terms.
PREREQUISITE: A grade of A- in DRAM 345/3.0, or permission of the Department.

KNPE 167.description:
An introduction to sociological thinking about sport and physical activity. Among the topics to be discussed are: an
exploration of what constitutes sport and under what conditions; how social relations of class, race, gender, and sexuality
shape sport experiences; the business of sport; and the relationship between the media and sport.
KNPE 167.title: Socio-Cultural Dimensions of Sport and Physical Activity
PREREQUISITE: Level 1 or above in a PHED or KINE Plan.

EXCLUSION: No more than 3.0 units from DRAM 211/3.0; DRAM 311/3.0.
DRAM 211.description:
An introduction to the history and theory of theatre conceived for audiences of young people. Students will read a variety
of plays intended for young audiences and consider the social and artistic issues associated with various dramatic and
theatrical techniques.
NOTE: Only offered online. Consult Arts and Science Online.
DRAM 211.title: Introduction to Theatre for Young Audiences
PREREQUISITE: Level 2 or above.

NOTE:
Students must submit in writing to the Music Office their request to apply for this course by the last day of classes
in the Winter Term.
MUSC 452.title: Electroacoustic Composition

COGS 100.description:
Introduction to Cognitive Science
A multidisciplinary approach to the study of the mind combining approached from philosophy, psychology, linguistics,
neuroscience, anthropology, and artificial intelligence. Logic, rules, concepts, and other mental representations used to
generate thought and behaviour. Implementation of computational and cognitive models of mental processes.
NOTE: Also offered online. Consult Arts and Science Online. Learning Hours may vary.
ONE-WAY EXCLUSION: May not be taken with or after CISC 352/3.0; PSYC 200/6.0.

EXCLUSION: No more than one course from HIST 218/3.0; HIST 301/6.0.
HIST 301.description:
Selected issues in the political, social and cultural history of Medieval Europe and the Mediterranean. Emphasis on scholarly
debates and the interpretation of primary sources in translation.
NOTE: In Fall Term, HIST 301/6.0 meets in the same classroom with HIST 218/3.0.
HIST 301.title: edieval Societies
PREREQUISITE: Registration in a HIST Major or Medial Plan.

EMPR 320.description:
This course introduces students to the various models of mediation used in the modern workplace to resolve conflicts as
well as a variety of other emerging alternative dispute resolution (ADR) processes. Students are introduced to the theory,
process, and practice of workplace mediation.
EMPR 320.title: Workplace Mediation and Alternative Dispute Resolution
PREREQUISITE: EMPR 200/3.0 or EMPR 220/3.0.

PHIL 318.description:
A survey of the central issues in the philosophy of law including a consideration of current jurisprudential controversies
